summary: Samir Ali, Jacob Holley, Stephen Justinen, Michael Pecaut, Seta Stanbouly and Michael Pekaut are the authors of the study at Loma Linda University School of Medicine . Ali, Justinen and Mecaut are members of the faculty of the L.A. omics program . The study was published in March 2013 .

The study was published at the Loma Linda University School of Medicine in California . The authors discuss spaceflight-Induced Gene Expression Profiles in the Mouse Brain . The author is Isaac Kremsky of the L.A. University of Medicine .
The article is published by the Loma Linda University School of Medicine in California . The author is Xiaowen Mao . The authors are divided in the Division of Biomedical Engineering Sciences (BMES)

The demands of deep space pose a health risk to the central nervous system that has long been a concern when sending humans to space . Little is known about how spaceflight affects transcription spatially in the brain .

The frontal cortex (FCT) plays a role in memory, attention, judgment, consciousness, and behavior . Pathophysiological changes in the FCT are associated with depression and anxiety . Ground-based analog studies have found that simulated microgravity influences cognitive function .

Q3 normalization was performed on the data for all downstream analyses . Normalized count values of gene expression were highly correlated across replicates of the four samples . Spaceflight had an effect on all four regions in SAL control animals . CA and DG were impacted the most .

Each brain region largely had a unique set of DEGs, though a small number were common to two or more regions . The top five DEGs by magnitude of fold change are as follows: <em>Ptgds, <em>.Cpne77, and <em >Cdkn2d; <em: Cdkn3d; >em>Ms  Many of these top-changing genes play important roles in apoptosis, cell cycle, neuroinflammation, neurotransmission, myelination, and mitochondrial and metabolic stress response . Alzheimer’s disease was the most frequent disease associated with the DEGs .

We also performed a permutation test (see <a href="#sec4-ijms-24-13569" class="usa-link">Section 4) in which genes were shuffled in order to randomly select up- and down-regulated BuOE-induced DEGs . For all brain regions, the number of random overlaps after 1000 permutations was never as large as

Space radiation may damage hippocampal cells, which are important for encoding new memories, spatial learning, and cognitive flexibility . The hippocampus is a site for neurogenesis as well . Space radiation has known associations with Alzheimer’s disease, as well as other neurological diseases .

Studies have shown spaceflight-induced increase in the production of lipid peroxidation products and decrease in antioxidant enzyme activity . The findings may provide novel insight into cellular mechanisms and operational risks that underlie the effects of spaceflight .

Ten-week-old C57BL/6 male mice were launched at the Kennedy Space Center (KSC) and spent 35 days aboard the International Space Station . Mice were exsanguinated by closed-cardiac blood collection under deep Ketamine/Xylazine (150/45 mg/kg) anesthesia, followed by cervical dislocation as a secondary euthanasia method .
Sequencing was performed on an Illumina NovaSeq 6000 (Illumina Inc., San Diego, CA, USA).
Fisher’s exact test was calculated on each 2 × 2 contingency matrix in order to obtain a p-value for the null hypothesis . For each brain region, a random set of BuOE-induced DEGs was selected .

The authors declare no conflict of interest . The author and contributors disclaim responsibility for any injury to people or property resulting from any ideas, methods, instructions or products referred to in the content .

The study was published in the journal One Journal . It is published on the journal's website . The authors include: Zhang, Zeng, Ouyang, Li, Guo, Zang and Ferguson . The study is published online at http://www.jpn.org/susi/jpn/2015/0135835 .
